newsitem.title: USA: ComEd says Zion nuke to shut for repair.
newsitem.headline: ComEd says Zion nuke to shut for repair.

text.p: Commonwealth Edison Co's 1,040 megawatt (MW) Zion nuclear power unit 1 in Zion, Ill. will shut down later Tuesday for a repair after a steady power reduction through the day, a company spokesman said.
"The unit will probably shut down sometime this afternoon or early this evening. They are operating at about 19 percent now," company spokesman Art Massa said Tuesday.
Massa said it was not yet known when the unit would resume operations, adding that it was being shut down for repairs to a motor operating valve on the pressurizing system.
Commonwealth Edison is a unit of Unicom Corp.
The Zion 1 unit resumed operations late last week after being shut August 18 due to problems in the main steam isolation valves.

Also, Commonwealth Edison's 789 MW Quad Cities unit 1 and 794 MW Dresden unit 2, both in Illinois, are currently in startup mode and expected to resume electricity production later this week, Massa said.
Quad Cities 1 was shut February 10 for refueling, while Dresden 2 was shut May 26 for general repairs.
Commonwealth Edison operates 12 nuclear power units in Illinois with aggregate output capacity of 11,487 MW.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
